overview: GitHub Mobile now lets you comment on unchanged lines within a file shown in a pull request’s Files Changed view by expanding the diff, bringing mobile commenting closer to the web experience.

detailed_explanation.title: What changed in Files Changed
bullets: In GitHub Mobile, you can now comment anywhere within a changed file, not only near the modified lines.
You can expand the diff to reveal unchanged code and leave a comment or suggested change where it’s needed.

detailed_explanation.title: Consistency with github.com
bullets: Comments added on unchanged lines on github.com are now displayed in GitHub Mobile.
This helps you review and respond from a phone without losing context that exists outside the immediate diff hunk.

detailed_explanation.title: Why it matters
bullets: Makes it easier to flag changes that should have been made beyond the current diff context.
Supports adding reviewer context or suggested changes on unchanged parts of a file.

detailed_explanation.title: Availability
bullets: The experience is available on the latest production build of GitHub Mobile for iOS and Android.
Minimum app version requirements are Not stated in the article.

key_changes: GitHub Mobile now supports commenting on unchanged lines in pull request files by expanding the diff.
Comments on unchanged lines created on github.com are visible in GitHub Mobile.
Users can add comments or suggested changes outside the immediate changed-line context.
impact: Reviewers using GitHub Mobile can leave more precise feedback without switching to the web UI.
Teams can discuss broader refactors or missing changes directly in the relevant unchanged code areas from mobile.
PR review workflows may become more consistent across web and mobile clients.
caveats: You need the latest production build of the GitHub Mobile app to access the feature.
Any limitations on which file types or diff views support this are Not stated in the article.
insights: The announcement emphasizes parity with the web experience (showing web comments on mobile) as a key usability goal.
The language focuses on reducing context loss in reviews, suggesting mobile PR review is being treated as a first-class workflow.
